Circus Mafia


Everyone at the circus was frantically practising for the next tour until the Ringmaster called a meeting. He had received information that some of the thirteen clowns recruited to perform were in fact looking to sabotage it, and bankrupt the beloved circus, putting the others out of employment. Can the loyal performers juggle out the bad apples, or will the sabotagers make a clown of the whole thing?



Spoiler: Alive

JarJarDrinks, Mafia Goon


Spoiler: Dead
grayfoxxxx, Town Follower, was lynched on Day One!

Ruleset (Stolen and slightly edited from Nikanor.)
General Rules:
1. Site Rules apply.
2. You may not quote your role PM, you may not quote any other PMs from me, and you may not quote the time at which I sent you any PM.
3. Blue is the colour I'll use to post vote counts, edit things into other people's posts, etc. Do not use this or impersonate me.
4. If you have a question or concern, or if you think that I may have made an error, do not hesitate to ask in-topic or by pm. Be sure to bold requests directed at me so that I see them.

Voting, Lynching, and Deadlines:
5. Votes must be bolded. Some mods require you to unvote before changing your vote; I do not.
6. A lynch requires a majority (over 50%) vote.
7. You may also vote for no lynch to happen on that day by typing Vote: No lynch. A no-lynch only requires a 50% vote to go through.
8. Each day will have a 2-week deadline. If you do not achieve a lynch before deadline, there will be no lynch.

Night Phase and Actions:
9. The night phase will last for 48 hours.
10. You may not use an ability on yourself unless otherwise specified.
11. If a limited-shot ability fails, the shot is still used, unless otherwise specified.
12. Night deadline might be extended if I need a replacement.

Prodding and Stuff:
13. If a player fails to post for 48 consecutive hours, he will be prodded. If that player does not post for another 24 hours after he's been prodded, he'll be replaced.
14. If you are going away, or if you have limited access to the site, notify me by pm or in-topic so that I know not to prod or replace you. If you're going to be V/LA over the night phase and have a night action, you may send in your action early. The maximum amount of time you may go without posting due to V/LA is 120 hours (five days).

Aristophanes:

-The main thing that made me start actually thinking Aris might be scum was that some of the points about Keyser in #100 seemed like they were reaching. Like saying that signaling to town that we're out of RVS was a play to look like town. Doesn't make sense to me. And saying that Keyser not understanding that Lapsa was quoting the wiki was "disingenuous." It seems much more likely to me, regardless of alignment, that Keyser just didn't know what Lapsa was posting. And there's not really a scum motivation for it, but Aris treats it as such. The reasoning just strikes me as the kind of thing scum would do when they know they're going after a wagon where the reasoning is already established but they don't want to look like they're just sheeping. So they heap on anything else they can find.
-Nothing else has really stood out to me as being alignment indicative.

BlueMoonRising:

-Not a whole lot yet, but for some reason I get a gut townvibe from his posts so far. Just the vote on Lapsa, the curtness, the (probable) wait-and-see approach...all things I feel like I see from town in early game. Not terribly strong, I'd call it a weak townlean and want to come back later. This is the kind of slot where other factors are better for reading the slot (not going to expand on that right now because if this slot is scum I don't want to give any ideas on what I'm looking for).
-EDIT AFTER INITIAL ENTRY: And then he goes and posts #210, in which he is directing play. There are a lot of scummy possibilities for this post, including coaching buddies, preemptively distancing himself from a mislynch and subtly trying to project an image of ignorance. The last sentence in particular bugs me because it seems like an afterthought; "Oh by the way I don't really know whether he's town."

Garmr:

-I get a minor townvibe from #70 given the way Garmr describes his RVS-stage attitude in #124. It just seems like Garmr trying to get things moving a little bit but he doesn't have a lot to go on. At the same time it's a very shallow push. Which basically means that Garmr isn't trying that hard to get things moving, and that can be antithetical to some scum's early-game mentality: to try to appear super towny.
-That being said, I was totally fooled by scumGarmr the last time I played with him so I don't know if I'll ever feel very comfortable townreading him this game.
-The push on Trivium (who is my top townread atm) gives me bad feelings, but at the same time it is literally impossible that the entire wagon is driven by scum so there must be some town out there who are on the wagon and just are not seeing what I'm seeing. I kind of knew that would happen because the post that made me townread triv the most is one that appears town to me because I know that I'm town.
-So basically my read on Garmr is somewhere between null and null-town, with a general wariness attached.

Gimlear:

-The questioning of Keyser (which may have actually sparked the early wagon on him), denouncing of the push on Keyser and subsequent L-1'ing of Trivium could come from either alignment. But if it does come from scum, it means Gimlear is a competent and thoughtful scum player. Which is just something I want to take note of for future assessment of the slot.
-That being said, the arc and posting style does feel genuine to me. So not interested in chasing Gimlear right now.

Grayfoxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx:

-Slight scumlean mostly just for #138. Looks like scum hesitation to appear too scummy while still wanting to hop on a juicy wagon. Other than that not much to go on. This early in the game I don't buy into lurking arguments too much.

JJD:

-JJD was the first, I believe, to jump on the Keyser thing. So while I do think it was low-hanging fruit for scum, I think you kind of have to give the benefit of the doubt to the first person to jump on the first wagon. That's just getting town out of RVS, which is something any alignment would do.
-The pushing on Keyser kinda strikes me as coming from town. Just seems like a natural path for town to go: sees something easy to talk about -> votes to get town out of RVS -> continues questioning player -> responses don't make much sense, and you're already voting them, so you continue to argue.
-Begins assessing how other players have interacted with the wagon in #153, which supports the get-town-out-of-RVS theory for his push on Keyser.
-Yeah I just see a lot of questioning and trying to move the game forward. Reads like town. Not that scum can't fake it, but this early in the game it feels towny to me.

Keyser:

-Don't buy the early-game arguments against Keyser about trying to look town. Yes, it's possible that's what he's doing. But I see no reason to believe that over the very plausible town explanation of "but he literally just wanted to know though."
-His responses to the pressure are a little illogical, but I still don't see a reason to read them as scummy. They actually ring towny to me because they come across like he's sure of himself and not trying to project an image, if that makes any sense...like here's an example. In #43 he responds to JJD by sarcastically saying "yes, scum have strong motivation to publicly look scummy." Like, the statement itself doesn't really make sense, and I feel like a more scummy approach would be to turn it around and start pushing a case on JJD or something along those lines.
-Generally he just comes across as a person who feels like it's obvious he's town, and the way I read that is that he thinks he should be obvtown because he knows that he's town.
-His switch to Performer in #196 amid continuing near-lynch status on the Trivium wagon also smacks of town to me. He didn't even back away from wanting to lynch Trivium, only suggested that we don't have to do it right now, so really as scum I think it would have been a better idea to keep pressure on Trivium without drawing attention elsewhere.


Lapsa:

-There are really only two things in Lapsa's ISO that I see to look at: his vote/unvote on Trivium and his vote on makara. The vote on Trivium put Triv at L-2, and then he unvoted after Gray put Triv at L-1 (and also after I suggested that we shouldn't lynch Triv). I can see scum motivation behind it, but the town explanation seems a bit more plausible to me (that Lapsa wanted to let more happen in D1/didn't feel that strongly about Triv being scum.) It also kind of seems antithetical to a scum mindset just because why would he want to work against a mislynch? (this is assuming the point of view of scumLapsa/townTriv)

Makara has probably posted the least out of all the players just because of the V/LA, and while Lapsa's vote didn't come with an explanation, I read it with an implication that Lapsa is trying to get makara to do more.
-Not sure what to make of Lapsa voting for BMR and makara in the same post. Maybe that's like a weird form of FoS?

makara:

-Don't see a whole lot to go on here. The catch-up post is the most substantive thing and that could really go either way.

Performer:

-Early-game enthusiasm could just be the excitement of a player who hasn't played much or a scum player hoping to come across as friendly/towny/fun. Not really sure which direction to go.
-Parts of #73 strike me as being pretty shallow, like the chiming in on the Keyser stuff. Which pings as scummy. He does say a couple ISO posts later that he doesn't want to lynch Keyser, but that's after I start arguing for Keyser being town.

Trivium:

But he goes back and explains his push on Keyser in #98 and it seems legit to me. So he's a new-ish player and gets a little overeager to find scum. Makes sense. -There's also his turnaround where he votes me amid orange-colored, all-caps excitement in #110/111. This looks -- again -- like excited town who think they've found a genuine scumslip (or something, I was never too clear on what his reasoning was). Zulfy:

Aris:

-Upon rereading #100, I can see where it would come from as town. It's confbias-y/reach-y, but I've found myself doing that as town before. I think this would come from eager town, which Aris certainly demonstrated with his first several posts that he was eager to start the game. So null on this I think. Want to try to look for more definitive things, as definitive as you can get in mafia anyway.
-#334 is a little suspicious to me though. He turns around on Keyser and says he thinks he was making something out of nothing, then starts looking on the Triv wagon for possible scum. Just seems like he was kind of following the way most people were going...
-The intent to hammer BMR in #409 also pings and fits in with the "going with the flow" hypothesis. It's definitely a hesitant post which fits in with expected scum approach to a mislynch, but obviously that only works if the BMR slot is in fact town.
-Yeah pretty wishy washy on this slot. I guess I would lean scum, the intent to hammer being the biggest thing. Looking at overall support for wagons might help my read here.

BMR/AP:

-Didn't really notice #83 before, in which he forgoes the Keyser wagon for Lapsa. Also kind of easy to pursue as scum, but Lapsa tends to attract suspicion from town as well for his playstyle.
-Then goes after JJD in #120 as well, which is not an easy place to be as scum I think. The combo Lapsa and JJD votes slide a little more town to me.
-#210 still sucks but I at least see town motivation for the last sentence that I didn't consider before, which is basically just trying to manipulate people into not hammering.
-I don't know...there's clearly a trend of going against the grain with most of the posts that BMR had, skimpy as they were. Which, if scum, I would guess would be an attitude of not wanting to be associated with mislynches. Idk...reading this again makes me think a little more town. The whole thing about continuing to post elsewhere on site while avoiding this game and then replacing out is a red flag for me, but there are many reasons a person might replace out. For this I think the acceptable town answer would have to be that he just didn't feel like putting in the effort to claw his way out of L-1. He already wasn't putting a ton of effort into this game so that explanation could fit.
-AP's replacing in makes me paranoid af. I know he's a good scum player (certainly was in person, and I know that can be very different from the way people play online, but I feel like he has a reputation on-site as being really good as scum as well) and I definitely see scummy possibilities here. Like he comes in and immediately starts trying to get people to unvote him, both explicitly (asking JJD to defend his reasoning in #425) and implicitly (#429, where he does a big catch-up post; the antithesis of BMR's inactivity that was clearly driving suspicion on the slot). The thing is that town doesn't want to be mislynched either, I know that for sure and I mislynched Titus in my last towngame when she replaced into a slot that was under fire near deadline too. So.
-I guess more than anything it's that AP seemed to go through the first several pages of the game looking for somebody to vote for, saw Keyser and slapped his vote there. Kind of supports the notion that he was just trying to get people off his back.
-Quite antsy about this slot. Another thing I have to take into consideration is the way this wagon built up, it seemed to grow pretty quickly and I could easily see some of the votes coming from scum. Whereas if this wagon was on scum then how would scum have interacted with it? I don't see a whole lot of arms-length buddying-type activity going on here, with the possible exception of Garmr saying he would be interested in seeing how the slot would flip but then not really seeming to want to vote it.

Garmr:

-One of the first proponents of a Triv wagon (pretty sure anyway).
-I don't understand the whole "Triv's lack of self-defense is scummy" thing. One, he was defending himself by the time Garmr posted #194. Two, why would scum not defend themselves?
-#301 is still weird, for reasons I've noted before. It's a reachy thing to suppose and I just don't see town pushing their scum buddy up to L-1 with the intention of making the wagon fall apart. Other reasons for pushing their buddy up to L-1, sure, but that? The logic is based on unrealistic assumptions, and while Garmr says later (#344) that he wasn't assuming this to be true, #301 is worded as an assumption: personally I think..."
-The main thing here is just Garmr really wanting to lynch Triv, to the point of coming up with reach reasoning to do so. I feel like that ties him to BMR/AP because he kept trying to get people back to the Triv wagon while BMR was being run up and why wouldn't scum want to push that? OK not sure if this is remotely helpful because some of the dots are hard to see and they're color-coded instead of labeled but here's a visual representation of Keyser's triv wagon narrative:

Spoiler: triv wagon momentum


All the data is based on Keyser's narrative, and I filled in data between the end of the narrative and Triv's claim.

Here's the key:

-Scumreads/leans/suspicions of triv are -1
-Votes on triv are -2
-Townreads/leans/defenses of triv are +1
-Unvotes off triv are +2

The idea was to try to capture how people interacted with the triv wagon as momentum shifted, but I think there are just too many people to really effectively show that. Oh well. If anybody has any ideas on how to make this more useful, let me know.

OK done some meta work on perf and I'm comfortable eliminating him from my lynch pool. Keyser I didn't really read the game he was in with you because I was looking for some specific things in his meta that didn't really apply in that game. Specifically I wanted to see his voting patterns as scum vs. town and whether his eager/excited/silly posting style was any different as scum vs. town. I wanted to focus on the early game for both of those things since that's the bulk of perf's posting in this game. He replaced in in the game he played in with you, so it wasn't a good example for my purposes.

It's interesting you say that perf's reads appeared to be more articulate and structured in his town games -- from what I saw, he looked like he put more work and explanation into his reads when he's scum (see the mystery mansion mafia game). For that reason he also appears to change votes less often as scum. Whereas in the town games I looked at, especially early in the game, he vote hopped like he does here.

I also feel like he was more eager/excited/silly in his posting when he played as town. That includes silly/strange photos and illustrations, "lol"s, etc. Which he's been doing here.

So basically it seems to me that perf's self-consciousness as scum manifests itself in some subtle ways like wanting to have his reads appear more ironclad and not feeling as able to post lightheartedly. Makes sense. I think a lot of players probably feel that way as scum.

Was looking through Garmr's ISO again and found myself seeing very possible scum motivation behind his arc. Like I think Garm is a pretty capable scum player and therefore think he could easily resist the temptation of going for every wagon that comes up and instead stick to his guns (which outwardly implies stubborn townie, but can also come from scum who don't want to do a ton of work or are having a tough time finding people they think genuinely look scummy).

So with Garm doggedly sticking to the Triv wagon to the very end, pushing against the BMR wagon and then hammering gray despite the claim, there are definitely probable explanations for both town and scum:

-Town: Really, really thought Triv looked bad and didn't know alignment of players telling him otherwise so didn't trust them. Thought BMR was town and therefore tried to get town not to mislynch. Didn't want to no lynch and figured that with triv's claim gray might be lying anyway.
-Scum: Thought triv looked bad and sensed that wagon could come back around to him, or couldn't find anyone else he really thought looked scummy enough to push without having to come up with a thin case. BMR was a buddy (feel like I have a reason not to believe this but I'd have to go back and look for it) or just didn't think BMR looked scummy enough to vote and knew he would have to explain himself if BMR was lynched and flipped town. Saw opportunity to hammer town PR in gray and took it, also knowing scum had a shot at a second PR that night and it was worth possibly getting lynched D2 to have two town PR investigatives gone.

Did a tiny bit of meta work with garm too because I was curious to see how stubborn he is about stuff/his approach to easy wagons. Garm was scum in Mini 1700 and resisted joining the wagon on Blocky (who ended up being the D1 lynch and was town), until the very end of D1 (from the timing it looked like a deadline lynch, much like in this game). Meanwhile Garm was pushing somebody else (fraggernaut) who wound up being town. So yeah, even if BMR/AP is town in this game, scumGarmr could have easily just resisted going for that wagon. And if BMR/AP is a scumbuddy, there's an obvious reason not to vote for it. Of note is that Garmr's approach to the blocky wagon in 1700 was not to defend it the way he defended BMR in this game, but rather to fence sit on that slot but stay off the wagon.

Also of not was that garmr voted fraggernaut early in that game and parked his vote there for a long time (he eventually unvoted and didn't vote again until hammering blocky).

I also looked at a game where garmr was town, NY 187 (pariah). In this one he also parked his vote on somebody early and stubbornly held onto it for most of D1.

So, lesson number one is that Garmr tends to latch onto a suspect early in D1 and cling stubbornly to it no matter what. That seems to be non-alignment indicative for him.

He actually held onto this one as the wagon built up and then fell apart, and he kept hanging onto it as town momentum built on prolapsed brain, who wound up being the D1 lynch and was town. Weird thing is, Garmr didn't mention prolapsed at all until after D1.

So yeah I don't really feel comfortable eliminating Garmr, and in fact might want to lynch him. woo moving backwards

His BMR vote also comes right as pressure is beginning to mount on BMR and uses others' reasoning.
-Supporting Garmr's weird point in #304 could just be a matter of opinion, or it could be because the suggestion that scum pushed Triv up to L-1 could come in handy for scumMak to use later. If we get a scumflip on the slot we should look at this post again.
-#477 also rings as convenient for scum: "The BMR replacement doesn't look as easy to lynch, good thing I left this back door open to get on the Triv wagon."

I see three completed games for mak, all three of which he was town in and all three of which are newbies:

-In 1651 he replaced in. His first reads list is very similar to this game, and his townreads are actually similarly thin in that game as well. His vote put a person at L-1 and that person wound up being town. So....not too far off from this game, actually.
-In 1654 he was replaced after 544 posts in the game (he made 63 posts). I believe that was the same time he replaced out of this game and for the same reasons. Anyway early on he sheeps somebody else and votes TSO, acknowledging he's sheeping. Votes crashingwaves in #117 partially because he's not posting very much, which smacks of his vote on BMR in this game. Again posts a reads list where the reasoning for his town reads is thin.
-So that leaves 1639, in which he played all the way through. Voting and reads lists seem a little different in this game, but that could be a product of the game environment.

OK, so...some of the things mak did in this game that looked pretty scummy are things he appears to do regularly as town. Not that that clears him or anything, but it does undercut the scumminess of those actions.

So they heap on anything else they can find.
-Nothing else has really stood out to me as being alignment indicative.

BlueMoonRising:

Not terribly strong, I'd call it a weak townlean and want to come back later. -EDIT AFTER INITIAL ENTRY: And then he goes and posts #210, in which he is directing play. There are a lot of scummy possibilities for this post, including coaching buddies, preemptively distancing himself from a mislynch and subtly trying to project an image of ignorance. The last sentence in particular bugs me because it seems like an afterthought; "Oh by the way I don't really know whether he's town."

Garmr:

-I get a minor townvibe from #70 given the way Garmr describes his RVS-stage attitude in #124. It just seems like Garmr trying to get things moving a little bit but he doesn't have a lot to go on. At the same time it's a very shallow push. Which basically means that Garmr isn't trying that hard to get things moving, and that can be antithetical to some scum's early-game mentality: to try to appear super towny.
-That being said, I was totally fooled by scumGarmr the last time I played with him so I don't know if I'll ever feel very comfortable townreading him this game.
-The push on Trivium (who is my top townread atm) gives me bad feelings, but at the same time it is literally impossible that the entire wagon is driven by scum so there must be some town out there who are on the wagon and just are not seeing what I'm seeing. I kind of knew that would happen because the post that made me townread triv the most is one that appears town to me because I know that I'm town.
-So basically my read on Garmr is somewhere between null and null-town, with a general wariness attached.

Gimlear:

-The questioning of Keyser (which may have actually sparked the early wagon on him), denouncing of the push on Keyser and subsequent L-1'ing of Trivium could come from either alignment. But if it does come from scum, it means Gimlear is a competent and thoughtful scum player. Which is just something I want to take note of for future assessment of the slot.
-That being said, the arc and posting style does feel genuine to me. So not interested in chasing Gimlear right now.

Grayfoxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx:

-Slight scumlean mostly just for #138. Looks like scum hesitation to appear too scummy while still wanting to hop on a juicy wagon. Other than that not much to go on. This early in the game I don't buy into lurking arguments too much.

JJD:

-JJD was the first, I believe, to jump on the Keyser thing. So while I do think it was low-hanging fruit for scum, I think you kind of have to give the benefit of the doubt to the first person to jump on the first wagon. That's just getting town out of RVS, which is something any alignment would do.
-The pushing on Keyser kinda strikes me as coming from town. Just seems like a natural path for town to go: sees something easy to talk about -> votes to get town out of RVS -> continues questioning player -> responses don't make much sense, and you're already voting them, so you continue to argue.
-Begins assessing how other players have interacted with the wagon in #153, which supports the get-town-out-of-RVS theory for his push on Keyser.
-Yeah I just see a lot of questioning and trying to move the game forward. Reads like town. Not that scum can't fake it, but this early in the game it feels towny to me.

Keyser:

-Don't buy the early-game arguments against Keyser about trying to look town. Yes, it's possible that's what he's doing. But I see no reason to believe that over the very plausible town explanation of "but he literally just wanted to know though."
-His responses to the pressure are a little illogical, but I still don't see a reason to read them as scummy. They actually ring towny to me because they come across like he's sure of himself and not trying to project an image, if that makes any sense...like here's an example. In #43 he responds to JJD by sarcastically saying "yes, scum have strong motivation to publicly look scummy." Like, the statement itself doesn't really make sense, and I feel like a more scummy approach would be to turn it around and start pushing a case on JJD or something along those lines.
-Generally he just comes across as a person who feels like it's obvious he's town, and the way I read that is that he thinks he should be obvtown because he knows that he's town.
-His switch to Performer in #196 amid continuing near-lynch status on the Trivium wagon also smacks of town to me. He didn't even back away from wanting to lynch Trivium, only suggested that we don't have to do it right now, so really as scum I think it would have been a better idea to keep pressure on Trivium without drawing attention elsewhere.


Lapsa:

-There are really only two things in Lapsa's ISO that I see to look at: his vote/unvote on Trivium and his vote on makara. The vote on Trivium put Triv at L-2, and then he unvoted after Gray put Triv at L-1 (and also after I suggested that we shouldn't lynch Triv). I can see scum motivation behind it, but the town explanation seems a bit more plausible to me (that Lapsa wanted to let more happen in D1/didn't feel that strongly about Triv being scum.) It also kind of seems antithetical to a scum mindset just because why would he want to work against a mislynch? (this is assuming the point of view of scumLapsa/townTriv)
-The makara vote supports the explanation of Lapsa wanting more things to happen in D1 as well. -Not sure what to make of Lapsa voting for BMR and makara in the same post. Maybe that's like a weird form of FoS?

makara:

-Don't see a whole lot to go on here. The catch-up post is the most substantive thing and that could really go either way.

Performer:

-Early-game enthusiasm could just be the excitement of a player who hasn't played much or a scum player hoping to come across as friendly/towny/fun. Not really sure which direction to go.
-Parts of #73 strike me as being pretty shallow, like the chiming in on the Keyser stuff. Which pings as scummy. He does say a couple ISO posts later that he doesn't want to lynch Keyser, but that's after I start arguing for Keyser being town.
-Jumps on the Triv wagon later (Perf says it's L-1 but for some reason I feel like he was mistaken), which is sketchy but not more sketchy than some of the other people on the wagon IMO.
-So yeah a scumlean here.

Trivium:

-I did think #59 was scummy. But it was surface-level scummy. It was the kind of thing that's really easy to call scummy. But he goes back and explains his push on Keyser in #98 and it seems legit to me. So he's a new-ish player and gets a little overeager to find scum. Makes sense. The fact that he comes right out and admits it, as Zulfy put it when I asked him about these posts, means he's either cleverly manipulative scum or very honest town. This looks -- again -- like excited town who think they've found a genuine scumslip (or something, I was never too clear on what his reasoning was). Zulfy:

I do think Lapsa and Aris are likely scum. Like if they aren’t partners I’m pretty sure one of them is scum. There are some alternate explanations for why scumLapsa would gambit like that that don’t involve Aris (just trying to confuse and distract town, for instance, or for towncred).

Another thing that makes me think Lapsa is scum aside from the fakeclaim itself is this disagreement between him and perf about what was said in the neighborhood thread. Performer says that he told Lapsa not to fakeclaim and Lapsa insisted on doing it anyway. Lapsa says that Performer told him not to fakeclaim and Lapsa agreed not to do it, then later changed his mind.

These are not opinions, these are facts that can be proven or disproven. So why would two players, who both have access to the thread that can prove or disprove a version of events, have two different versions of the same event? My thought is that Lapsa needs town to believe his narrative in order to support his justification for fakeclaiming: he first agreed, which clears the way for him to later change his mind because “town was pulling apart.”

Meanwhile, that explanation doesn’t make a lot of sense. Lapsa thought fakeclaiming would help town work together and get a better idea of where scum are? No. In theory there’s no reason to think that muddying up the waters makes them clearer. In reality, the fakeclaim led to a mislynch.

In #554 (D1), he says “If I had a role worthy of CCing a cop, I would have done it in this post.” In #1489 (D3), he says “I doubt there are any other PRs out there at all.” That was before AP claimed vanilla. Those posts together just read like AP looking at the game through a VT’s eyes. He certainly didn’t leave a back door open to fakeclaim a PR later. Zulfy I have my doubts about but am leaning town. His voting record is also not the greatest, though I don’t think voting record can be used reliably in this game with the number of wagons on town we’ve had that so many people have participated in. I pointed out before that Zulfy has had some posts that look like towny paranoia and that still rings true. If we get a scumflip in Aris or Lapsa, associatives might help read Zulfy better. Funny enough, I don't think its that ridiculous. I'm reading a book right now called "User Story Mapping". Its basically about how to communicate as a team effectively in order to write software. That may seem mostly unrelated, but one of the key points in the book is that "shared documents does not mean shared understanding". Basically people misunderstand each other regularly; even when reading the same material they may interpret it in different ways. So while that may only seem peripherally related to the the Neighborhood discussion here, this is basically how I feel about it: That different narratives of what happened in the neighborhood is really not that alarming. VOTE: Zulfy

I expect to be lynched Today, but that will take the game to 3p lylo after which is not the worst thing in the world.

Waiting for AP's response, as well as the following wall, is all about due diligence -- considering the possibilities before making a decision.

First off, I see no reason for Zulfy to lie here and I believe his claim, as well as his result. But...

Possibility that Zulfy is telling the truth and AP is still town

With this much town power, it would make sense for scum to have a second investigative role. By my reckoning, the only one that would keep open the possibility for AP to be town is mafia watcher/voyeur. It works out like this:

-Zulfy is almost certainly not lying and is probably the night kill tonight. He kinda crumbed, it makes very little sense for a scumZulfy to fakeclaim right now, the setup spec he did kinda makes sense and it explains a lot of his actions.
-AP has claimed VT, so him performing a night action as town can't be the reason the motion detector was tripped last night.
-It would be crazy as shit for town to have any more PRs (besides, we've massclaimed and nobody else has claimed a PR), so that can't be the reason the motion detector was tripped.
-AP claimed yesterday. So if he's town, there would be no reason for most scum PRs to target him. Obviously he wasn't the kill choice, there would be no reason to roleblock him with other townies having yet to claim, and investigative roles would have no reason to target him...unless they were investigative roles that get information on somebody other than the target, in other words a watcher or voyeur or something like it. In that case, it would make sense for scum to target somebody they feel would be a likely town PR target at night.

Spoiler: Speculation that is perhaps unnecessary
Now, a scumwatcher's choice of target gets complicated because IMO it depends on how much info scum has. We have to assume that makara got a result before the slot was lynched, though with makara's activity level it's possible that they didn't I suppose. But the result could have been nothing because they were a rolecop (for instance, what if makara investigated Keyser N1 and that's the reason Zulfy's detector was tripped that night?).

If scum was under the impression that town had no power roles left save for Perf, whose one shot had already been used up, then a scumwatcher's target last night would probably be "idk just choose somebody, you probably won't get a result anyway." But if they had reason to suspect that somebody else was a PR, for instance if gim is town and scum fell for his attempt to hint that he was a PR, then a scumwatcher would want to target whoever they suspected that that PR would want to target.

Unfortunately, at this part of the hypothetical scenario we're making so many assumptions that continuing to theorize won't be very useful. Just wanted to follow the thought to its conclusion.


Given the amount of power town has, I think it's a given that scum has to have something besides an odd-night rolecop. Whether a watcher or voyeur-type role is likely is something we could debate, but I don't know how we could distinguish between the likelihood of scum having some PR with scum having one of those specific PRs.

So to recap, the way I see it is that either AP is scum or scum has a watcher/voyeur-type role.

If AP is scum I am going to buy him a freaking drink or something the next time I see him because bravo.

Lynching order

I'd like to point out that Aris's approach to Zulfy's claim kinda looks bad regardless of AP's alignment because Aris immediately latched onto Zulfy's claim with no questioning and voted AP.

Spoiler: side note
I am aware that JarJar did the same thing, but JarJar's associatives with mak/sky and his overall play make him very unlikely scum imo.


So if AP is scum, Aris's immediate vote looks like bussing. If AP is town, it looks like Aris taking advantage of an easy mislynch in the face of town wanting to lynch Aris.

The second one is actually less convincing to me than the first because I would think scum might temper their enthusiasm a bit for a wagon they know is on town. But still a likely scenario imo.

Is it a better idea to lynch Aris before AP? I honestly don't know. I want to consider that some.

AP's response to Zulfy's claim

AP's response to all of this was to assert that Zulfy is lying and vote him. This actually looks pretty bad for AP imo. First, he says that follower, cop and neighborizer is a fair amount of power for town to have, but then says later that it doesn't make sense for scum to have another PR. Those two ideas conflict with each other -- if town has a lot of power, it would make sense for the mod to balance that out by giving scum power.

Second, he doesn't consider the circumstances surrounding Zulfy's claim, like the fact that fakeclaiming scum would have to expect they would be lynched the next day when AP flipped town.

What this looks like to me is scumAP in a corner and searching for a way out. He sees the possible explanation of scum targeting him at night and tripping Zulfy's motion sensor, but for some reason doesn't point to that as the likely explanation for Zulfy's result.

Why? My theory is that AP is trying to hide his knowledge about his own team's PRs/not give any info to town on what scum might have. That explains his assertion that scum having a second PR is unlikely despite the amount of power town has.

Final thoughts

So there is a possibility that Zulfy is telling the truth and AP is still town, but I don't think we can really guess at the likelihood of that scenario without more information. AP's response makes me think it's more likely that he's just scum.

And while Aris does look bad, and has for a while, part of my read on him is based on AP. If we lynch AP and he flips town then imo Aris might actually look a little less like scum, and maybe we lynch somebody else instead.

So I do support an AP lynch. But no need to rush.

So what do we have in the way of reading Lapsa? We have his votes, and we have a steady stream of posts where he pushes and prods various people in one way or another -- what I believe to be his brand of scumhunting.

His votes are all over the place and clearly do not follow momentum with the exception of the BMR wagon (note to self: should we get a scumflip on either of those slots, that should very much be considered.) I tend to think that that's more likely to come from town, but...it's not the most convincing thing ever.

Since I'm on a bit of a meta streak I'll do a little work with Lapsa's meta too. Let's see what we can find.

-Mini 1636: Lapsa was VT (pretty sure vanilla anyway). Votes were all over the place, posting style was similar to this game.
-Newbie 1548: Lapsa was town tracker. Vote hopped a little but kept it on Thor most of the day. Longer posts in a back-and-forth with Thor, but Thor tends to spur on that kind of thing and Lapsa's replies were still short quips, just several short quips packed into one post.
-Mewbie 1538: Lapsa was VT and replaced in in post #143. So he only was in the game for like four days before D1 ended, and he only had one vote.
-Mini 1652: Lapsa was town vig. He vote hops pretty much the same way he did in this game. Posting style is similar to this game.
-Mini 1666: Lapsa was VT. Vote hopped a fair amount. Lol like every time Lapsa is in a game with VDA he votes him. Posting style is similar to this game.
-Mini 1687: Lapsa was VT (I was in this one with him). Vote hopped a bit but parked on Thor and Math/Pers for a while. Posting style was similar to this game.
-NY 188: Lapsa was werewolf gunsmith (it was multiball). Vote hopped quite a bit, including one on his partner so let's remember that should we get a scumflip from Lapsa this game. The posting style is similar to this game in that it's mostly short quips and he posts a lot of silly gifs/youtube music, but...it kinda feels a little different. His sentences are more complete, more well-structured. He seems to explain things a little bit more.

Long and short of it -- Lapsa always posts like this and always vote hops. The one scum game I could find provides a minor reason to townread him IMO just because of the differences in posting style.

I'm eliminating him from my lynch pool today.

Spoiler: ISO reads
Aristophanes:

-The main thing that made me start actually thinking Aris might be scum was that some of the points about Keyser in #100 seemed like they were reaching. Like saying that signaling to town that we're out of RVS was a play to look like town. Doesn't make sense to me. And saying that Keyser not understanding that Lapsa was quoting the wiki was "disingenuous." It seems much more likely to me, regardless of alignment, that Keyser just didn't know what Lapsa was posting. And there's not really a scum motivation for it, but Aris treats it as such. The reasoning just strikes me as the kind of thing scum would do when they know they're going after a wagon where the reasoning is already established but they don't want to look like they're just sheeping. So they heap on anything else they can find.
-Nothing else has really stood out to me as being alignment indicative.

BlueMoonRising:

-Not a whole lot yet, but for some reason I get a gut townvibe from his posts so far. Just the vote on Lapsa, the curtness, the (probable) wait-and-see approach...all things I feel like I see from town in early game. Not terribly strong, I'd call it a weak townlean and want to come back later. This is the kind of slot where other factors are better for reading the slot (not going to expand on that right now because if this slot is scum I don't want to give any ideas on what I'm looking for).
-EDIT AFTER INITIAL ENTRY: And then he goes and posts #210, in which he is directing play. There are a lot of scummy possibilities for this post, including coaching buddies, preemptively distancing himself from a mislynch and subtly trying to project an image of ignorance. The last sentence in particular bugs me because it seems like an afterthought; "Oh by the way I don't really know whether he's town."

Garmr:

-I get a minor townvibe from #70 given the way Garmr describes his RVS-stage attitude in #124. It just seems like Garmr trying to get things moving a little bit but he doesn't have a lot to go on. At the same time it's a very shallow push. Which basically means that Garmr isn't trying that hard to get things moving, and that can be antithetical to some scum's early-game mentality: to try to appear super towny.
-That being said, I was totally fooled by scumGarmr the last time I played with him so I don't know if I'll ever feel very comfortable townreading him this game.
-The push on Trivium (who is my top townread atm) gives me bad feelings, but at the same time it is literally impossible that the entire wagon is driven by scum so there must be some town out there who are on the wagon and just are not seeing what I'm seeing. I kind of knew that would happen because the post that made me townread triv the most is one that appears town to me because I know that I'm town.
-So basically my read on Garmr is somewhere between null and null-town, with a general wariness attached.

Gimlear:

-The questioning of Keyser (which may have actually sparked the early wagon on him), denouncing of the push on Keyser and subsequent L-1'ing of Trivium could come from either alignment. But if it does come from scum, it means Gimlear is a competent and thoughtful scum player. Which is just something I want to take note of for future assessment of the slot.
-That being said, the arc and posting style does feel genuine to me. So not interested in chasing Gimlear right now.

Grayfoxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx:

-Slight scumlean mostly just for #138. Looks like scum hesitation to appear too scummy while still wanting to hop on a juicy wagon. Other than that not much to go on. This early in the game I don't buy into lurking arguments too much.

JJD:

-JJD was the first, I believe, to jump on the Keyser thing. So while I do think it was low-hanging fruit for scum, I think you kind of have to give the benefit of the doubt to the first person to jump on the first wagon. That's just getting town out of RVS, which is something any alignment would do.
-The pushing on Keyser kinda strikes me as coming from town. Just seems like a natural path for town to go: sees something easy to talk about -> votes to get town out of RVS -> continues questioning player -> responses don't make much sense, and you're already voting them, so you continue to argue.
-Begins assessing how other players have interacted with the wagon in #153, which supports the get-town-out-of-RVS theory for his push on Keyser.
-Yeah I just see a lot of questioning and trying to move the game forward. Reads like town. Not that scum can't fake it, but this early in the game it feels towny to me.

Keyser:

-Don't buy the early-game arguments against Keyser about trying to look town. Yes, it's possible that's what he's doing. But I see no reason to believe that over the very plausible town explanation of "but he literally just wanted to know though."
-His responses to the pressure are a little illogical, but I still don't see a reason to read them as scummy. They actually ring towny to me because they come across like he's sure of himself and not trying to project an image, if that makes any sense...like here's an example. In #43 he responds to JJD by sarcastically saying "yes, scum have strong motivation to publicly look scummy." Like, the statement itself doesn't really make sense, and I feel like a more scummy approach would be to turn it around and start pushing a case on JJD or something along those lines.
-Generally he just comes across as a person who feels like it's obvious he's town, and the way I read that is that he thinks he should be obvtown because he knows that he's town.
-His switch to Performer in #196 amid continuing near-lynch status on the Trivium wagon also smacks of town to me. He didn't even back away from wanting to lynch Trivium, only suggested that we don't have to do it right now, so really as scum I think it would have been a better idea to keep pressure on Trivium without drawing attention elsewhere.


Lapsa:

-There are really only two things in Lapsa's ISO that I see to look at: his vote/unvote on Trivium and his vote on makara. The vote on Trivium put Triv at L-2, and then he unvoted after Gray put Triv at L-1 (and also after I suggested that we shouldn't lynch Triv). I can see scum motivation behind it, but the town explanation seems a bit more plausible to me (that Lapsa wanted to let more happen in D1/didn't feel that strongly about Triv being scum.) It also kind of seems antithetical to a scum mindset just because why would he want to work against a mislynch? (this is assuming the point of view of scumLapsa/townTriv)
-The makara vote supports the explanation of Lapsa wanting more things to happen in D1 as well. Makara has probably posted the least out of all the players just because of the V/LA, and while Lapsa's vote didn't come with an explanation, I read it with an implication that Lapsa is trying to get makara to do more.
-Not sure what to make of Lapsa voting for BMR and makara in the same post. Maybe that's like a weird form of FoS?

makara:

-Don't see a whole lot to go on here. The catch-up post is the most substantive thing and that could really go either way.

Performer:

-Early-game enthusiasm could just be the excitement of a player who hasn't played much or a scum player hoping to come across as friendly/towny/fun. Not really sure which direction to go.
-Parts of #73 strike me as being pretty shallow, like the chiming in on the Keyser stuff. Which pings as scummy. He does say a couple ISO posts later that he doesn't want to lynch Keyser, but that's after I start arguing for Keyser being town.
-Jumps on the Triv wagon later (Perf says it's L-1 but for some reason I feel like he was mistaken), which is sketchy but not more sketchy than some of the other people on the wagon IMO.
-So yeah a scumlean here.

Trivium:

-I did think #59 was scummy. But it was surface-level scummy. It was the kind of thing that's really easy to call scummy. But he goes back and explains his push on Keyser in #98 and it seems legit to me. So he's a new-ish player and gets a little overeager to find scum. Makes sense. The fact that he comes right out and admits it, as Zulfy put it when I asked him about these posts, means he's either cleverly manipulative scum or very honest town. Taking into account Triv's experience and posting style, it makes more sense to me that he would be very honest town.
-There's also his turnaround where he votes me amid orange-colored, all-caps excitement in #110/111. This looks -- again -- like excited town who think they've found a genuine scumslip (or something, I was never too clear on what his reasoning was). This doesn't seem like the kind of thing a new scum player would think to do.

Zulfy:

-Not really sure what to make of the early-game pre-flip association stuff. I guess I could see him using it as town as just a thought organizer, but then scum can use those techniques as a means to force their reads into a more genuine-looking perspective. So. Null I guess.
-His positioning on the Trivium wagon is prime scum real estate. The positioning is honestly the thing that made me raise an eyebrow when he made the vote. His reasoning, which goes above some other peoples' reasons for voting Triv, are actually not all that bad.
-Not a big fan of #191. It's like he's giving himself an out in case he wants to bail from the Trivium wagon.
